Award.AwardTitle: Sampling and Inference in Network Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The study of complex networks constitutes an interdisciplinary area of inquiry that transcends traditional knowledge domains by focusing on the fundamental interdependencies of components within various systems-of-interest. Examples abound from social networks to coupled human and natural systems, from financial networks to disease systems, and from telecommunication networks to energy and power systems. It is the interconnection among these components that often sit at the heart of our most vexing global grand challenge problems, including climate change, energy demands, security, health and wellness, and livelihood and poverty. The study of such complex systems and often large scale networks -- understanding their intrinsic properties, changes to their structure over time or due to external factors, multi-scale behavior of individuals to coarser grained modular communities -- can afford important insights to individuals, organizations and society at large when tackling such grand challenge problems.

This project seeks to develop robust and scalable sampling methods for the modeling and analysis of large, potentially dynamic, networks. Sampling is often touted as a means to efficiently combat the inherent complexity of estimating the relevant characteristics of a population. Sampling a network is complicated because they are composed of two units (nodes and edges) that are not always nicely nested. A key objective will be to study and provide a sound mathematical basis along with high performance tools for both node-centric and edge-centric sampling methodologies for the analysis and modeling of networks. The objective of realizing high performance tools for real world applications, drawn from social networks and network biology, will be equally significant, and is necessary for sustained innovation of an inter-disciplinary nature. This research will shed light on the theoretical underpinnings of graph sampling and probabilistic inference in both the static and dynamic network contexts. From an educational standpoint, the investigators will train the next generation of graduate students in this interdisciplinary arena and will also actively encourage participation of undergraduates and under-represented minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The study of complex networks constitutes an interdisciplinary area of inquiry that focuses on the fundamental interdependencies of components within various systems of interest. Examples abound from social networks to coupled human and natural systems, from financial networks to disease systems, and from telecommunication networks to energy and power systems. It is the interconnection among these components that often sit at the heart of our most vexing global grand challenge problems, including security, health and wellness, and livelihood and poverty. The study of such complex systems and often large scale network structures -- understanding their intrinsic properties, changes to their structure over time or due to external factors, multi-scale behavior of individuals to coarser grained modular communities -- can afford important insights to individuals, organizations and society at large when tackling such grand challenge problems.


With respect to intellectual merit this project sought to develop robust and scalable methods for the modeling and analysis of large, sometimes dynamic, networks by leveraging sampling. Sampling is often touted as a means to efficiently combat the inherent complexity of estimating the relevant characteristics of a population. Sampling a network is complicated because networks are composed of two types of units (nodes and edges) that are not always nicely nested. A key contribution of this project is a simple and efficient algorithm based on edge sampling and likelihood maximization to detect change points in dynamic networks under the snapshot model. The utility of this algorithm is demonstrated on both synthetic and real-world networks drawn from political science. Following this initial effort, a hierarchical change point algorithm is implemented to distinguish intra- from inter-community changes in dynamic networks, and the method is applied to detect economic crises in the international trade network.

In additional to practical algorithm designs a central goal was to study and provide a sound mathematical basis along with high performance tools for both node-centric and edge-centric sampling methodologies for the analysis and modeling of networks. There are two threads for this objective, which shed light on the theoretical underpinnings of graph sampling and probabilistic inference in network contexts. In one thread, threshold-growth dynamics are leveraged to improve community coverage of node samples in networks with community structure. This work is complemented by foundational research on the behavior of cascade dynamics on structured networks with overlapping communities. In a second thread, the first theoretical guarantees for Jaccard based edge-sampling is given, which is commonly used for de-noising network structures. This work also demonstrates the technique's utility in inferring the structure of a hidden space from its observed noisy graph representation.

With respect to broader impacts, the investigators have trained four graduate students in this interdisciplinary arena – two of whom have completed their PhD work (including one female student) and the others making good progress towards their respective degrees. The Principle Investigator created a new course on network science, which attracted students from Mathematics, Statistics, Physics and Computer Science at both the undergraduate and graduate level. This course served as a useful vehicle for research activities in pedagogy arising in this project. The Co-Principle Investigator led an interdisciplinary Networks Reading Group, which attracted graduate students and faculty from Mathematics, Statistics and Computer Science. All software artifacts completed by project team members as it relates to this project have been released to the public domain.
